questions.question: I once studied classical music ……………… six months.
questions.description: We use 'for' with a period of time.

questions.question: That house has been empty …………….. six months.
questions.description: Use 'for' with a period of time.

questions.question: I am going to France ……………… the summer.
I have known him ………………. our school days.
questions.description: We use since with the starting point of actions or situations.

questions.question: I have known him ……………… a long time.
How long have you been here ………………?
questions.description: We use for to indicate duration.

questions.question: I haven’t met him ………………… months.
questions.description: After negatives and superlatives, 'in' can be used to talk about duration.

questions.question: It was the worst storm ………………… decades.
questions.description: After negatives and superlatives, 'in' can be used to talk about duration.

questions.question: He loved music ……………….. his earliest childhood.
questions.description: 'From' can be used with a present perfect tense in expressions that mean 'right from the start'.

questions.question: I will be at home ........................... morning on.
questions.description: Both since and from can be used to give the starting point of actions. Since is mainly used with perfect tenses. From is used in other cases.
